Award.AwardTitle: Constraint Release Dynamics in Entangled Polymers
Award.AbstractNarration:
TECHNICAL SUMMARY:

Mixtures of a monodisperse linear polymer with a monodisperse "star"-branched polymer represent the simplest polymers that expose the greatest deficiencies in current understanding of "constraint release" -- the effect that motion of one polymer chain has on its entanglements with other chains. This problem will be attacked by (1) obtaining a series of carefully synthesized star 1,4-polybutadiene polymers, which are then thoroughly characterized by the most advanced method available, namely temperature gradient interaction chromatraphy, or TGIC, (2) formulating and measuring the rheology of a set of some 40 mixtures of "star"-branched and linear polymers covering a range of constraint-release conditions, (3) applying the most advanced "tube" theories to predict the rheology of these mixtures and other such mixtures already available in the literature, and (4) collaborating through an international network, thereby accessing new polymer materials, dielectric relaxation data on cis-polyisoprene star/linear mixtures, and accessing results from "slip-link" and molecular dynamics polymer simulations for the prediction of the rheology and dielectric relaxation of these star/linear blends.


NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY:

Polymers are among the most widely used synthetic materials; over 300 million tons are produced annually, for use in automobiles, medical supplies and equipment, wrappings for food preservation, and many other applications. The manufacture of such polymers in the United States is now increasingly attractive, due to cheap and abundant sources of natural gas, from which the starting chemicals for common polymers, such as polyolefins, are obtained. To economize on the quantity needed and to speed and cost-reduce the shaping of polymers into products, the flow properties of polymers must be optimized. This often involves the strategic addition of controlled amounts of long-chain branching to the polymer molecules. However, design of branching strategies depends on a thorough knowledge of polymer dynamics, which is currently inhibited by lack of understanding of a phenomenon called "constraint release" -- the effect that motion of one polymer chain has on its entanglements with other chains. This proposal represents a direct attack on this unsolved problem, using advanced tools of polymer synthesis and newly discovered methods of characterization of branching at unprecedented levels of accuracy. Understanding will be greatly enhanced by collaborating with an international team, which includes the most knowledgeable scientists in the world on various aspects of the problem, including synthesis (in Saudi Arabia, Korea, and the U.S.), characterization (in Korea and Japan), and computational modeling (in the U.S. and United Kingdom). The research will create the most complete body of experimental work on "constraint release" in branched polymers, and the data and theories will be made available to industrial researchers through publication, web-based access, and direct interaction with industrial researchers. Ph.D., Undergraduate, and High School students will be trained in the course of the research.

Institution.Name: Regents of the University of Michigan - Ann Arbor
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN

POR.DRECONTENT:
The aim of the work is to develop the ability to predict the dynamics of polymer chains that are dense enough and long enough to entangle with each other, as is commonly the case in most polymers used commercially.  The ability to predict these dynamics controls how well one can design and synthesize them for use, and how to process or shape them into final usable form. In this grant, we tackle perhaps the hardest problem involved in developing such predictive capability, and that is the influence that the dynamics of one polymer molecule has on the dynamics of a neighboring chain with which it is entangled.  The motion of one chain can release an entanglement interaction on a neighboring chain, allowing that chain to change its configuration and thereby relax its share of the polymer stress.  Since polymers used commercially or in consumer products are invariably mixtures of molecules of different length and often different branching structure, a key factor limiting our ability to predict their mechanical behavior is our incomplete understanding of this process, particularly in mixtures containing both branched and linear polymers. 

In the work done under this proposal, strides were made in clearly delineating the most important gaps in our understanding of polymer entanglement constraint release and how to fill these gaps. We focused on a key test of constraint release dynamics by studying the rheological, or flow, properties, of a mixture of monodisperse linear polymer with monodisperse star polymer, containing a single branch point and four arms emanating from this branch point. The star polymer was synthesized by our collaborators in the group of Professor Jimmy Mays at the University of Tennessee.

The standard theory of polymer diffusion and relaxation assumes that the constraining effects of entanglements act to confine the given chain to a “tube”-like region.  We used this theory to predict the rheological properties of pure linear, pure star, and mixtures of star and linear polymers. We were able to predict the rheology of the pure star and pure linear polymers. However, the standard theory predicts very poorly the behavior of the blends.  We were able to obtain excellent predictions, however, using a simulation that treats entanglement points as dynamic “slip links,” whose dynamics are controlled by the motions of surrounding chains. The much better success of the slip link model, relative to the tube model suggests that entanglements between polymer chains need to be treated as discrete objects and cannot readily be smeared into a mean-field “tube,” at least when complex constraint release events occur, as is the case when star polymers entangle with linear ones.  These insights will be critical in the development of more realistic theories for the mechanical properties of polymers. 

The research work carried out here has been disseminated in papers and presentations, including in a Keynote Lecture at the International Congress on Rheology in Kyoto, Japan in August, 2016. The work has led to training of two Ph.D. students, Priyanka Desai, now employed at Shell Development Company in Houston, Texas, and current student Ryan Hall, an African American Ph.D. student.  It also led to the training of undergraduate female student Qifan Huang, who is now a Masters of Science student at Stanford University. In addition, PI Larson and graduate student Ryan Hall taught polymer science principles at two elementary Schools in Detroit, serving primarily minority students, namely Priest Elementary School and MacKenzie Elementary; see Fig. 1. The work also featured in a short course on rheology taught in June 2016 at the University of Minnesota to 20-30 industrial and other researchers, and in a short course on rheology at the Society of Rheology meeting in Baltimore on Oct. 10-11, 2015. Finally, an international faculty member, Seung Joon Park, from the Korea Polytechnic University, Siheung, Korea, visited the Larson group for a year, and the collaborative efforts led to a publication.
